aCGTRx-y6.memHandModelNotes: Migrates up to several hundred meters between breeding pools and adjacent nonbreeding terrestrial habitats (NatureServe 2004).  Within lacustrine habitat species will be found only in shallow water (NatureServe 200).  Since matrix systems span all moisture regimes (Xeric to Mesic) for the system,  I added landform to restict the spp to pixels that would be dry to mesic.  Excluding the species from summits and steeps slopes should exclude those more Xeric pixels (ALS Jan 04).

habitat_description:
*Range and habitat description overlap with Hyla versicolor.

Cope’s gray treefrog (diploid) occurs in most of the southeast including Marion County, Florida, but also in New Jersey, the Potomac River valley, the Piedmont and Coastal Plain of Virginia. Reports of this species include Illinois, Indiana, southern Ohio, southwest Iowa, Arkansas, Missouri, Louisiana, Oklahoma, and a small area in Texas. Other areas where this species occurs may include in the prairies of northeaster and southeastern South Dakota (Ballinger et al. 2000; Dodd 2013). Distribution of this species overlaps with the range of the gray treefrog (H. versicolor; tetraploid) in Maryland, southeaster West Virginia, south central Virginia, and in general from eastern Kansas to east Texas. Furthermore, overlap may occur in the unglaciated Allegheny Plateau (Little et al. 1989), southeastern Manitoba, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Iowa, North Dakota, and in through south and northwestern Michigan. At least in Wisconsin, it has been described that Cope’s gray treefrog are present in higher numbers than gray treefrogs in the southeastern prairie regions (Casper 1998). In general, habitat includes trees and shrubs found in or near water only descending at night for chorus and breeding (Behler and King 1979). Limited data is available comparing historical and current distribution (Lannoo 2005).

Cope's gray treefrog, is often associated with hardwood or mixed pine-hardwood forests, woodlands and woodland edges. Breeding typically occurs in small ponds, borrow pits, roadside ditches, beaver ponds, or other standing water.  These treefrogs are also found in recently disturbed areas,with abundant shrubs, herbaceous growth, and vines (Wilson 1995). ALS jan 04

Ecosystem Classifiers:  Hardwood Forest/Woodland (excluding xeric), Mixed Forest, All Mesic Forests including maritime and some montane, Wetlands-excluding Lakes/Rivers/Pondshore- emergent vegetation). ALS Jan 04
